Certainly! One example of how lighting has been used to influence the audience's perception of characters in a famous play is the opening scene of Shakespeare's "Macbeth." 

In this scene, the three witches are introduced, and they have a significant impact on the play's overall tone and themes. The lighting in this scene is dark, with only dim illumination from a few torches, creating a tense and eerie atmosphere. This lighting helps to emphasize the witches' supernatural and sinister nature and raises suspicion about their motives.

Similarly, in Act IV, Scene 3, when Macbeth meets the witches again, the lighting is low, creating a feeling of unease and darkness. This lighting reinforces the idea that Macbeth's encounter with the witches is ominous and dangerous.

In both instances, the lighting plays a pivotal role in shaping the audience's perception of the witches and their influence on Macbeth's journey. The audience sees them as dark, foreboding figures, reinforcing their negative reputation and the ominous nature of the play's events.
